div.p:
An Inquisicion taken at the Guyldhall within the said Cittie of Bristoll the five and Twentyth day of Aprill in the Yeares of the Raigne of orour Soveraigne Lord [James by the] obscured by snake weight grace of God [King of]obscured by snake weight England Scotland ffraunce and Ireland defendordefendor of the
fayth etc vi‚Åät videlicet of England ffraunce and Ireland the seaventh and of Scotland the xlijth before Sr Sir George Snygg knight one of his Barrons of his Exchequar Thomas Younge [of the city of Bristol] obscured by snake weight esquyer Israell Gleson of the same Cittie Bacheler of law and
John Younge of Clifton in the Cowntie of Gloucester gentleman by vertue of his Maiesties Comission under the greate Seale of England bearing date the xviijth daye of July in the sixth yeare of his high[nes king of]obscured by snake weight England ffraunce and Ireland and of Scotland the one and
fortyth unto us and others directed and unto this Inquisicon anexed To inquire aswell by the othes of twelve lawfull men or more of the said Cittie of Bristoll and Countie of the same as by all other good and and lawfull wayes and meanes according to [the true]
meaninge of one statute made in the highe Courte of parliament holden the xxvijth day of October in the xliijth yeare of the raigne of the late Queene Elizabeth of famous memorie intituled an acte to redresse the misimployment of landes goodes and [stockes]
of money heare tofore geven to charitable uses What landes Tenementes Re[ntes] Annuities profittes hereditamentes goodes Chattelles mony or stockes of mony have at any tyme or tymes heretofore beene geven lymitted appoynted or Assigned by the [Kinges]
Excellent Maiestie or any of his noble progenitors or by any other wel[l d]isposed persones or persones bodies politique or corporate for the releife aged ympotent and poore people, maintenance of sicke and maimed souldiers, or mariners, [Schools]
of learning, free schooles, or Schollers in universities, repayre of Bri[d]ges, Portes, Havens, Causwayes, Churches, Seabankes, or highwayes, educacon or preferment of Orphanes, Releife, Stocke or mayntenance for howses of Correcon mariadges [of poore]
Maides, Supportacion aide or helpe of younge tradesmen, handicraftes men or persones decayed, releife or redempcion of prisoners or Captives, or aide or ease of any poore inhabitant concerninge payment of fifteenes, setling out of Souldiers, or other Taxes in any [parish]
Towne or place within the said Cittie of Bristoll and Cowntie of the same, And of all and singuler the abuses, misdemeanors breaches of trustes misimploymentes, not ymployinge, Concealinge, defraudinge, misconceiving, or misgovernment of the [same landes]
Tenementes Rentes Annuities proffittes Hereditamentes goodes Chattelles money stockes of money or any of them heartofore geven lymitted appoynted or Assigned to or for ant the Charitable and godly uses before rehearsed accordinge to [the] true [meaning]
of the said statute by the oathes of George Harrington George Harrington, Alderman of Bristol, died 1639/40? TNA PROB 11/182/150, John Doughtie John Doughtie, Mercer and Alderman of Bristol, died 1629/30? TNA PROB 11/157/167, Robert Rogers Robert Rogers, Alderman of Bristol, died 1633? TNA PROB 11/163/452, Hugh Perd Hugh Pearde, Grocer of Bristol, died 1617/18? TNA PROB 11/131/257, John W[...]ward John Woodward, Fletcher of Bristol, died 1612? TNA PROB 11/119/562, Richard Reece Richard Rice, Woollen Draper of Bristol, died 1627? TNA PROB 11/152/759 Thomas Whitchead, Thomas Cecill, Thomas Cecill, Gentleman of Redcliffe, died 1631? TNA PROB 11/160/77 ffrauncis Blont Francis Blount, Ironmonger of Bristol, died 1630? TNA PROB 11/158/5, Raphe Wright Ralph Wright, Mercer of Bristol, died 1640? TNA PROB 11/184/304, Thomas Cowley, Mathew Warren Mathew Warren, Clothier of Bristol, died 1635?, ffrauncis [...] [...]
Johnson, John Ware, Thomas Michell, John Northall, and Humfrey Bryne, lawfull men of the said Cittie who beinge chardged to inquire of the premisses and therunto chosen tried and sworne say uppon their oathes That the late [prince of]
famous memorye Kinge Henry the Eight for and in consideracion of the laudable purpose of SrSir Thomas West knight Lord La Ware, George Croft Clerke, Robery Thorne of London Merchant, Nicholas Thorne Alderman of the same Cittie [of Bristoll]
and John Goodriche Clerke, Executors of the last will and Testament of Robert Thorne sometyme of Bristol Merchaunt deceased father of the said Nicholasm in the ereccion foundacion surpportacion of a perpetuall free schole of G[rammar]
of one Schoolmaster and one or two ushers to be established within the said Cittie and lymittes of the same, by his lettres patentes bearinge at Chelsehith the xvijth day of in the xxiijth yeare of his Reigne Did geve and graunte Licence for [him]
his heires and Successors to the Maior Burgesses and Cominaltie of the then Towne and now Cittie of Bristoll and to their Successors that they and their Succssors might at any tyme then after purchase receave and [take] to th[em]
and to their Successors the howse and hospitall of the Bartholmews in Bristoll aforesaid. And All Mannors landes messuages Tenementes Gardens Orchardes Meadowes leasows pastures Woodes Rentes Revercions and services and hereditamentes with [all their]
rightes proffittes and comodities that then or at ant tyme thertofore were accepted reputed or taken as parcell or member of the posessions of the said hospitall, or that the said George Croft then MrMaster of the said hospitall had held or did enioye
in the right of the said hospitall, aswell within the said Cittie of Bristoll and Suburbes of the same, as in the parishes of Clifton, Stapleton, Sodbury and Wickware in the Cowntie of Gloucester wthinwithin the Cowntie of the Cittie of Bristoll and
the Cowntie of Gloucester, or ellswere within the Realme of England, to the cleare yearly value of fortie poundes over and above all chardges aswell of the said SrSir Thomas West Knight late Lord Ware Patron and founder of the said hospitall
as of the said George Crofte Clerk MrMaster of the said howse and hospitall, and the brothers and Sisters of the same or of any other person or persones having or pretendinge any right or title to the premisses though they were holden of the said late Kinge h[is]
heires or Successors in cheife or otherwise To have to the said Maior Burgesses and Comminaltie and to their Successors for ever to theeuses and intentes aforesaid. And also by the same did graunte his speciall licence to the same person
that they might geve the said howse or hospitall Mannors Landes Tenementes and Hereditamentes and other the premsses unto the Mayot Burgesses and Comminaltie of Bristoll and to ther Successors for ever, as by the same lettres Pa[tents] [...]
And that ther were afterwardes one or more Recoveries in due forme of law suffered and had beweene the said parties or some of them for the setlinge of the saod landes and premisses wthwith Thappertenances that the same should be had [...]
according to thintent aforesaid And that after such Recoverye and Recoveries and Entry made into the premisses The said Robert Thorne of London merchaunt and the said John Godriche clerke died thereof seased and [...] [Nicholas]
Thorne brother of the said Robert overlived them, and was sole sized in the premisses in his demeane as of ffee by Title of Survivor. And so beinge seased caused - - - - Grammer Schoole to be estabished wthin within the said howse of the Bart[holmews] [...]
place and set one John Hurrys Schoolemaster to teach grammer within the same. And that afterwardes before any futher Assuraunce or establishment therof made, the said Nicholas Thorne died. And the premisses discended and came to Robert [Thorne]
Sonne and heire of the said Nicholas, wchwich said Robert before any estate executed died without yssue. By reason whereof the premisses discended unto Nicholas Thorne of the Cittie of Bristoll merchant as x x x x nexte heir to the said Robert [Thorne]
and also to the said Nicholas his father. And that he the said Nicholas Thorne the Sonne by his deed in writinge under his hande and seale bearinge date the first day of July in the yeare of or our Lord god 1561 and in the third year of the Reig[ne of]
the late Queene Elizabeth by vertue of the said lettres Patentes in thaccomplishment aswell of the good purpose and will of the said Robert his Uncle, and the said Nicholas his father, as also for thestablishment and perpetuall contin[uation]
of a free schoole erected, or to be erected wthinwithin the said howse of the Bartholmews of one schoole master and one or two ushers, as need and occacion thenafter should serve to teach and bring up youth and others in learninge and vertue [and]
especially in Grammer and other good literatures for the better educacion and bringinge up of Children and others that would resorte thether for learninge of Grammer and understandinge to th honor of God [and]
thadvauncement of the said Cittie Did geve graunte and confirme unto the Maior Burgesses and Cominaltie of the said Cittie of Bristoll and to their Successors for ever the said house or late hospitall called the Barth[elmews]
scittuate in Bristoll aforesaid wthallwithall howses Edifices and buildinges therunto belonginge or in any wise apperteyninge And all messuages Gardens Orchardes landes Tenementes Meadowes pastures revercions services and Rentes wthin within the [...]
of the said Cittie of Bristoll And all other Mannors Landes Tenementes Meadowes pastures woodes underwoodes Rentes Revercions and services and all other hereditamantes in Kingsmarshe and wthin within the parishes of Clyfton Wickwarre, Sodbury and
elswheare wthin within the said Cowntie of Gloucester specified in the said two severall Recoveryes sometyme parcell of the possessions of the saod late hospitall in as lardge and ample manner as the same came or of Right out to come [...]
handes and posession of the said Robert Thorne his uncle and to the said Nicholas Thorne his father and to the said John Godriche Clerk or any of them by vertue of the said two severall Recoveries and licence aforesaid To [be] had
and enioyed to the said Maior Burgesses and Cominaltie of the Cittie of Bristoll and to their Successors for ever to the uses and intentes of the findinge of a free Grammer schoole wthinwithin the said house called the Bartholmewes
for ever. And to find one sufficient and able person beinge sufficiently learned and vertuos to be Schoole master ther and one or two other sufficient person or persones beinge also sufficiently learned and vertuos to be [usher or]
ushers there. And they the said Master and usher or ushers and their Successors continually to teach Grammer within the said Schoole to all children and other that would repayre to the said Schoole for learninge and knowledge of the [latin tongue]
and other good learninge for the better Educacion and bringing up of youthe in learninge and vertue. And that freely without any thinge to be taken other then fower pence only for the first Admission of every scholer into the same [...]
Hold the premisses of the cheefe Lordes of the ffee by And the service therfore due and accustomed as by the said recited deed likewise appeareth And the sayd Jury do further saie uppon their oathes that x x x x x x x x x x x x x [...]
x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x [...] x x x x x x x x parchment scraped and crosses added he the said Nicholas Thorne beinge heire unto the said Robert Thorne his uncle and Nicholas Thorne his father and pretendinge to inherite the same landes Tenementes and hereditamentes procured a Conveyance in fe[...]
under the yearly Rent of Thirty Poundes only from the Maior and Cominaltie of the said Cittie And afterwards died having yssue Alice Katherine and Murabell his daughters and heires And the said Alice maried and tooke to Husband one John [Pyke ...]
who pretending to have the Interest of all the said landes and hereditamentes long deleyned the said yearly Rent and lately died and everysithence his decease the said Alice and Nicholas Pykes Sonne of the said John and Alice and [d...]
other persones from by and under the said John Pykes knowinge of the said trust do now pretend to have the Interest of all the said Landes Tenementes and Hereditamentes in ffee ffarme as aforesaid from the said Maior
and Comynaltie And the sayd Jury do ffuther saie uppon their oathes that all the messuages landes Tenementes Gardens Orchardes and Hereditamentes whatsoever belonging to the said howse called the Barthomews
and at this tyme discovered to the said Jury are conteyned in the schedule to the said Inquisicion affixed and are in the severall handes of the Tenamentes and occupies therin mencioned, and do and of long tyme have paid the yearly
Rentes theruppon reserved to the said Nicholas Thorne the sonne and to his heires and assignes for every of their said severall Tenementes or holdinges as in the said Schedule is also declared And the sayd Iurors uppon their oathes
do further saie That all the landes Tenementes and Hereditamentes in the said schedule mencioned at the tyme of the first foundacion and establishment thereof to the purposes and intentes aforesad were of the cleare yearly value Lij li xij d
upwards and now are of a farre greater value over and above all charges and reprises And that all the Rentes and proffittes of the said landes Tenementes and hereditamentes in the said schedule named were [...]
and so ought to have beene ymployed accordinge to thintent and true meaninge of the donors and first founders therof ( Except the abuses breaches of trust necligences misimploymentes no imploying [...] [...]
misconvertinge and misgovermentes heareafter specified ffor the said Iurors so saie uppon their oathes that the said Nicholas Thorne the sonne did unduely procure a conveyance of all the said landes and premisses in fee ffarme
unto himselfe from the said Maior and cominaltie payinge for the same but only the yearly Rent of Thirty powndes, whearas it is manifest that the same landes and premisses were of greater value by the yeare as
aforesaide, and so hath beeneheld and enioyed by the said Nicholas Thorne the sonne and his Assignes in his lyfe tyme, and After x x x x x the decrease of the said Nicholas, by the said John Pyks deceased, and thence his decease by [and]
the said Alice and Nicholas their Sonne to the defraudinge of the true intencion of implyment of the saod landes Tenementes and Hereditamentes and of the proffittes therof, and to the decaye of the Schoole ?the Schoole master
and the other said uses. And that the deedes of and concerninge the same landes and Hereditamentes or the most materiall of then and come now to the handes custody of the said John Pykes his heires or assignes
by the undue course aforesaid ( as they thinke ) of the said Nicholas Thorne the sonn the sonne In wittnes wherof Iurors aforesaid to this present Inquisicion have set their handes and Seales the daye and yeare furst
above written
